metadata.title: SA5 Forms Library - Complete Documentation
metadata.description: Enhanced Webflow form capabilities with data-binding, webhook handling, and advanced form features

overview.purpose: Enhance Webflow's native forms with advanced capabilities
overview.description: This library contains features to enhance Webflow's native forms with three primary feature-sets: data-binding, IP info retrieval, and webhook handling.

feature.name: Data-binding
feature.description: Initialize form fields with data, such as the current user's email address, or information from the querystring or a cookie

capabilities.capability: Populate Form SELECTs with dynamic data from Webflow Collection Lists
Support for form INPUTs (textboxes) using HTML5's autocomplete features
Use Collection List's built-in sorting and filtering options

feature.name: IP Info
feature.description: Similar to data-binding, retrieve and store the user's geoip information such as country, city, and IP they're submitting the form from

feature.name: Webhook Handling
feature.description: Form submission can be sent to external services like Zapier, Make, or form handlers like Basin. SA5 handles both transmission and response processing

benefits.benefit: Display appropriate success/failure messages based on webhook results
Maintain Webflow's inline success/error message functionality

standard_installation.location: Add to site-wide custom code HEAD area of your site
standard_installation.version_note: IMPORTANT: We've made some enhancements to SA5 Core in v5.5.0. If you are already using other SA5 Libs, please make certain to upgrade them to at least v5.5.0 as well to ensure cross-compatibility.

developer_installation.description: For SA5 library developers, use the extended syntax to support Sygnal DevProxy

post_installation.note: Once you've added the library, add the custom attributes for the features you need, described in each feature separately.

feature.name: Data-binding Form INPUTs & SELECTs
feature.description: The original feature SA was built around - populate Form SELECTs with dynamic data from Webflow Collection Lists, plus support for form INPUTs using HTML5's autocomplete features

how_it_works.step: Creating a JSON datasource using a Webflow Collection List
Processing that JSON into HTML and linking it to the INPUTs and SELECTs you designate
how_it_works.benefits: Setup is relatively simple, and you can use the Collection List's built-in sorting and filtering options to precisely control the data you want in your Form controls

step_1.description: Paste this code into the Before </body> tag script area of your Page settings

step_2.title: Create a Collection List Data Source
step_2.description: Setup your Collection List Data Source following the instructions for datasources
step_2.requirements: This needs to be accessible on any page(s) that you'll be doing data-binding

step_3.title: Setup your Form

instructions.instruction: Select the INPUT Textbox or SELECT List that you're wanting to data-bind
Add a custom attribute directly to that form control, with the name `wfu-bind`. This tells WFU that you want to bind this control to a datasource
For the value, enter the data source name that you chose above

step_3.note: If you are binding a SELECT you may wish to remove the default values that Webflow has created. WFU will not delete them.

nocode_setup.step_1: First, add the library as detailed in Quick Start
nocode_setup.step_2: Setup your attributes (see above for details)

checklist.check: Double-check that you have the custom attribute `wfu-data` = (your data source name) on the outermost part of the Collection List
Double-check that you have the custom attribute `wfu-bind` = (your data source name) on the INPUT or SELECT that you're wanting to data-bind
Double-check that your datasource name is exactly the same on both
Double-check that you have the script inserted in the right place in your page or site configuration
Make sure that your filter, sort, and item limit settings on your Collection List actually retrieve the data you want
Run through the instructions above again and re-verify everything

issue.name: Weird data on Form Posts
issue.input_elements: For INPUT elements, the value posted is whatever the user types in that textbox
issue.select_elements: For SELECTS, the value posted is the `id` you specified in your script block. Make sure you chose the right field for that, and that you have no extraneous spaces

feature.name: Smart Form Webhook Handler
feature.description: Post form data direct to webhooks, while supporting Webflow's inline success/error messages

version_updates.update: Redefined the `other` handler to recognize error codes as errors, and to display the form's error message accordingly. If you need the original behavior where success is assumed regardless of the response code, use the new `success` handler
Adds Basin support, to help alleviate SPAM and form handler issues

overview.problem: Webflow forms can be redirected to a webhook for external processing, but Webflow does not have any built-in way to handle the webhook's response. By default, instead of a "success" message, the user sees the JSON response itself
overview.solution: SA5 Forms bridges that gap by submitting form data to webhooks, analyzing responses, and displaying appropriate success/failure messages

workflow.step: Submits your form directly to the webhook you choose
Analyzes the response to determine success or failure
Displays the form success or failure message, depending on that result
On successful submit with redirect URL configured, gives submit button "Please wait..." text and redirects the page

setup_steps.step: First, add the library as detailed in Quick Start
Setup your webhook handlers on Basin, Zapier, Make, n8n, or your form handler or automation provider of choice. Design it to accept HTTP POST requests
Link your Webflow form by setting the action to your webhook URL. Copy the webhook URL and in the Webflow designer, paste it into the `Action` setting of the form
Design the form however you like
Set the form method to POST
Make sure to customize your success and fail messages too for clarity

form_configuration.location: Add to the Form Block element (not the Form element)

handler.name: other
handler.description: For all other webhooks - relies on response codes (200-299 = success)

handler.name: success
handler.description: To assume success on any response

handler.name: Zapier
handler.behavior: Looks for "success" in the response, and displays the success message if present
handler.note: Zapier's success response only indicates that the data was received successfully. It does not indicate that the Zap ran successfully

handler.name: Make
handler.behavior: Can handle specific responses and display error messages, if you use the HTTP Response node in Make
handler.note: If you have the request return immediately, you will simply get 'Accepted' from Make as the success text

handler.name: n8n
handler.behavior: Can handle specific responses and display error messages

handler.name: Basin
handler.behavior: Shows success and fail messages depending on Basin's response

handler.name: Other
handler.behavior: Relies on the webhook to return a meaningful response code. Responses in the range 200-299 are considered success, and anything else is considered an error
handler.use_case: Most useful for unknown webhook providers and simple form submissions like newsletter enrollments

handler.name: Success
handler.behavior: Always displays the success message, regardless of the response code
handler.use_case: Use when success/failure aren't that important, you just need to indicate to the user that their work is done

key_advantages.advantage: Immediate form processing, with no delays
No need to use Webflow's built-in forms email notification system
Make the form behave like a normal webflow form post, where it stays on the same page, and displays the form's success message
Handle error scenarios better, including unique server side logic and error messages (with Make & n8n)
